Bone formation arises via two overlapping yet distinct mechanisms (1Olsen B.R. Reginato A.M. Wang W. Annu. Rev. Cell Dev. Biol. 2000; 16: 191-220Google Scholar). Endochondral ossification occurs via the calcification and vascularization of an initial cartilaginous template, best exemplified by long bone development and fracture repair. Non-endochondral ossification occurs during development in the flat bones of the skull, in teeth, and in the lateral portion of the clavicles. Direct bone deposition occurs in type I collagen-based extracellular matrix; no cartilage template precedes bone deposition. Both in vivo and in cell culture models, a characteristic gene expression program is elaborated as osteoblasts differentiate and mature from osteoprogenitors (2Stein G.S. Lian J.B. Endocr. Rev. 1993; 14: 424-442Google Scholar, 3Yamaguchi A. Komori T. Suda T. Endocr. Rev. 2000; 21: 393-411Google Scholar, 4Canalis E. Economides A.N. Gazzerro E. Endocr. Rev. 2003; 24: 218-235Google Scholar). Although transcription factors crucial to bone development (Runx2/Cbfa1, CBF-β, Msx2, Msx1, Dlx5, Alx4, Osx, and Sox9) and metabolic/endocrine regulation (multiple nuclear receptors, Runx2/Cbfa1) have been identified, our understanding of the molecular details of stage-specific osteoblast gene expression is rudimentary (5Karsenty G. Endocrinology. 2001; 142: 2731-2733Google Scholar). “Cross-talk” between these factors occurs in the osteoblast nucleus; an integrative model is lacking and sorely needed to better address unmet clinical needs in metabolic bone disease, craniofacial dysmorphias, and hetero-topic ossification (6Karsenty G. Nature. 2003; 423: 316-318Google Scholar, 7Demer L.L. Tintut Y. Arterioscler. Thromb. Vasc. Biol. 2003; 23: 1739-1743Google Scholar). The osteoblast homeodomain protein Msx2 plays an important role in bone formation and the temporospatial timing of osteoblast differentiation (8Cohen Jr., M.M. J. Craniofac. Genet. Dev. Biol. 2000; 20: 19-25Google Scholar). Maas and colleagues have disrupted the mouse Msx2 gene by homologous recombination and identified severe deficiencies in both intramembranous and endochondral bone formation (9Satokata I. Ma L. Ohshima H. Bei M. Woo I. Nishizawa K. Maeda T. Takano Y. Uchiyama M. Heaney S. Peters H. Tang Z. Maxson R. Maas R. Nat. Genet. 2000; 24: 391-395Google Scholar). Indeed, in the simultaneous absence of Msx2 and Msx1, a highly related and partially redundant Msx gene family member, craniofacial skeletal development is completely abrogated (9Satokata I. Ma L. Ohshima H. Bei M. Woo I. Nishizawa K. Maeda T. Takano Y. Uchiyama M. Heaney S. Peters H. Tang Z. Maxson R. Maas R. Nat. Genet. 2000; 24: 391-395Google Scholar). In humans, Wilkie and colleagues demonstrated that haploinsufficiency for Msx2 function results in substantial calvarial mineralization defects; this manifests either as hereditary parietal foramina (10Wilkie A.O. Tang Z. Elanko N. Walsh S. Twigg S.R. Hurst J.A. Wall S.A. Chrzanowska K.H. Maxson Jr., R.E. Nat. Genet. 2000; 24: 387-390Google Scholar) or as part of a cleidocranial dysplasia syndrome (11Garcia-Minaur S. Mavrogiannis L.A. Rannan-Eliya S.V. Hendry M.A. Liston W.A. Porteous M.E. Wilkie A.O. Eur. J. Hum. Genet. 2003; 11: 892-895Google Scholar). Conversely, Msx2(P148H), a gain-of-function variant of Msx2, causes craniosynostosis, characterized by the precocious mineralization and differentiation of calvarial osteoblasts in cranial sutures. Recent studies in our lab have shown that Msx2 can promote the osteogenic differentiation of vascular progenitors, promoting osteoblast lineage allocation while inhibiting adipogenic potential (12Cheng S.L. Shao J.S. Charlton-Kachigian N. Loewy A.P. Towler D.A. J. Biol. Chem. 2003; 278: 45969-45977Google Scholar). In this setting, the craniosynostosis variant Msx2(P148H) is much more active than wild-type Msx2 in promoting osteogenic differentiation in synergy with bone morphogenetic protein 2 (12Cheng S.L. Shao J.S. Charlton-Kachigian N. Loewy A.P. Towler D.A. J. Biol. Chem. 2003; 278: 45969-45977Google Scholar). However, Msx2 also clearly functions to delay the timing of osteoblast terminal differentiation. This is best exemplified by Msx2-dependent suppression of the osteocalcin (OC) 1The abbreviations used are: OC, osteocalcin; OPN, osteopontin; MINT, Msx2 interacting nuclear target; RRM, RNA recognition motif; FGF, fibroblast growth factor; FGFR, fibroblast growth factor receptor; OCFRE, osteocalcin FGF response element; TAF, transcriptional activation function; RNAP IIo, RNA polymerase II with phosphorylated large subunit C terminal domain; CMV, cytomegalovirus; NMTS, nuclear matrix targeting sequence; AD3, activation domain 3; RT, reverse transcription; EGFP, enhanced green fluorescence protein; PBS, phosphate-buffered physiological saline; ChIP, chromatin immunoprecipitation assay; siRNA, small interfering RNA; ROS, rat osteosarcoma cells; RNAi, RNA interference; G4, yeast gal 4 DNA binding domain; Osx, osterix; SFG-LacZ, retrovirus expressing β-galactosidase; SFG-Msx2, retrovirus expressing Msx2; Tbdn100, Tubedown 100. 1The abbreviations used are: OC, osteocalcin; OPN, osteopontin; MINT, Msx2 interacting nuclear target; RRM, RNA recognition motif; FGF, fibroblast growth factor; FGFR, fibroblast growth factor receptor; OCFRE, osteocalcin FGF response element; TAF, transcriptional activation function; RNAP IIo, RNA polymerase II with phosphorylated large subunit C terminal domain; CMV, cytomegalovirus; NMTS, nuclear matrix targeting sequence; AD3, activation domain 3; RT, reverse transcription; EGFP, enhanced green fluorescence protein; PBS, phosphate-buffered physiological saline; ChIP, chromatin immunoprecipitation assay; siRNA, small interfering RNA; ROS, rat osteosarcoma cells; RNAi, RNA interference; G4, yeast gal 4 DNA binding domain; Osx, osterix; SFG-LacZ, retrovirus expressing β-galactosidase; SFG-Msx2, retrovirus expressing Msx2; Tbdn100, Tubedown 100. gene in teeth and calvarial osteoblasts (13Hoffmann H.M. Catron K.M. van Wijnen A.J. McCabe L.R. Lian J.B. Stein G.S. Stein J.L. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1994; 91: 12887-12891Google Scholar, 14Bidder M. Latifi T. Towler D.A. J. Bone Miner. Res. 1998; 13: 609-619Google Scholar, 15Newberry E.P. Latifi T. Battaile J.T. Towler D.A. Biochemistry. 1997; 36: 10451-10462Google Scholar, 16Newberry E.P. Boudreaux J.M. Towler D.A. J. Biol. Chem. 1997; 272: 29607-29613Google Scholar). During odontogenesis, where stage-specific gene expression programs are spatially resolved, Msx2 and OC are reciprocally expressed (14Bidder M. Latifi T. Towler D.A. J. Bone Miner. Res. 1998; 13: 609-619Google Scholar). Consistent with this, stable expression of Msx2 in MC3T3E1 calvarial osteoblasts suppresses OC, but not osteopontin (OPN), gene expression (14Bidder M. Latifi T. Towler D.A. J. Bone Miner. Res. 1998; 13: 609-619Google Scholar). Unlike recent observations demonstrating that activation of early osteogenic differentiation (e.g. alkaline phosphatase expression) is proportional to Msx2 DNA binding activity (12Cheng S.L. Shao J.S. Charlton-Kachigian N. Loewy A.P. Towler D.A. J. Biol. Chem. 2003; 278: 45969-45977Google Scholar), suppression of the late phenotypic marker OC is independent of intrinsic Msx2 DNA binding (15Newberry E.P. Latifi T. Battaile J.T. Towler D.A. Biochemistry. 1997; 36: 10451-10462Google Scholar). Inhibitory protein-protein interactions occur in part between Msx2 and DNA-protein complex assembled by the OC promoter region -154 to -113 (16Newberry E.P. Boudreaux J.M. Towler D.A. J. Biol. Chem. 1997; 272: 29607-29613Google Scholar, 17Newberry E.P. Latifi T. Towler D.A. Biochemistry. 1998; 37: 16360-16368Google Scholar, 18Willis D.M. Loewy A.P. Charlton-Kachigian N. Shao J.S. Ornitz D.M. Towler D.A. J. Biol. Chem. 2002; 277: 37280-37291Google Scholar). Because this element also mediates transcriptional responses to activated FGFR1/FGFR2 receptor tyrosine kinase, we called this region the OCFRE (18Willis D.M. Loewy A.P. Charlton-Kachigian N. Shao J.S. Ornitz D.M. Towler D.A. J. Biol. Chem. 2002; 277: 37280-37291Google Scholar, 19Newberry E.P. Boudreaux J.M. Towler D.A. Mol. Endocrinol. 1996; 10: 1029-1040Google Scholar, 20Yu K. Herr A.B. Waksman G. Ornitz D.M. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 2000; 97: 14536-14541Google Scholar). The OCFRE is a 42-bp DNA domain that encompasses recognition cognates for Runx2 and a novel Ku-antigen transcription factor complex (18Willis D.M. Loewy A.P. Charlton-Kachigian N. Shao J.S. Ornitz D.M. Towler D.A. J. Biol. Chem. 2002; 277: 37280-37291Google Scholar). It is noteworthy that this GT-rich duplex DNA is also recognized by MINT, a large ∼400-kDa nuclear matrix protein that we first identified by expression cloning using radiolabeled Msx2 (21Newberry E.P. Latifi T. Towler D.A. Biochemistry. 1999; 38: 10678-10690Google Scholar). MINT is a nuclear DNA- (21Newberry E.P. Latifi T. Towler D.A. Biochemistry. 1999; 38: 10678-10690Google Scholar) and RNA- (22Shi Y. Downes M. Xie W. Kao H.Y. Ordentlich P. Tsai C.C. Hon M. Evans R.M. Genes Dev. 2001; 15: 1140-1151Google Scholar) binding protein highly expressed in central nervous system, lymphoid tissue, cardiac tissue, and calvarial osteoblasts (21Newberry E.P. Latifi T. Towler D.A. Biochemistry. 1999; 38: 10678-10690Google Scholar, 23Kuroda K. Han H. Tani S. Tanigaki K. Tun T. Furukawa T. Taniguchi Y. Kurooka H. Hamada Y. Toyokuni S. Honjo T. Immunity. 2003; 18: 301-312Google Scholar). GT-rich cognate recognition is conferred by the three N-terminal RRM domains of MINT (21Newberry E.P. Latifi T. Towler D.A. Biochemistry. 1999; 38: 10678-10690Google Scholar). MINT is highly homologous to Drosophilan spen, a transcriptional co-regulatory protein genetically identified as regulating fly head development in concert with Hox homeodomain proteins (24Wiellette E.L. Harding K.W. Mace K.A. Ronshaugen M.R. Wang F.Y. McGinnis W. Development. 1999; 126: 5373-5385Google Scholar) and receptor tyrosine kinase signaling cascades (25Rebay I. Chen F. Hsiao F. Kolodziej P.A. Kuang B.H. Laverty T. Suh C. Voas M. Williams A. Rubin G.M. Genetics. 2000; 154: 695-712Google Scholar). Thus, biochemical and genetic studies place MINT in regulatory pathways under the control of homeodomain transcription factors. Given the above, we sought to characterize the biochemical relationships between MINT, Msx2, and FGFR2-responsive components of the OCFRE. MINT enhances transcription driven by FGFR2 from the OCFRE in MC3T3E1 osteoblasts that possess endogenous Runx2. We identify that Runx2 possesses the FGFR2-activated transactivation function (TAF) in this complex. In the naive CV-1 cell background, we reconstitute FGFR2 and Runx2-dependent activation of the OCFRE. MINT and Runx2 act synergistically to enhance OCFRE activity, but only in the presence of activated FGFR2. This action is dependent upon Runx2 activation domain 3 (AD3) and the MINT RRM domains. By contrast, Msx2 suppresses OCFRE activation by Runx2 and MINT, and chromatin immunoprecipitation assays (ChIP) assays reveal that Msx2 displaces Runx2 from OC, but not OPN, chromatin. In confocal microscopy experiments, MINT localizes with phosphorylated RNA Pol II (RNAP IIo), indicating that MINT associates with transcriptionally active chromatin complexes. The limited overlap between MINT and Runx2 is enhanced 2.5-fold by FGF2 stimulation, providing additional evidence that FGF signaling regulates Runx2-dependent transcription. Thus, MINT enhances Runx2 and FGFR2 activation of multiprotein complexes assembled by the OCFRE. Msx2 targets this complex as a mechanism of selective transcriptional inhibition. In osteoblasts, MINT may serve as a nuclear matrix platform that organizes and integrates osteogenic transcriptional responses. Plasmid and Eukaryotic Expression Constructs—One-hybrid experiments were carried out using pFA-CMV to generate fusion proteins with the yeast Gal4 DNA binding domain and pFR-LUC as the Gal4-responsive reporter (Stratagene, La Jolla, CA). Fragments for murine Runx2 (isoform II), murine Ku70 (GenBank™ accession number P12956), murine Ku80 (GenBank™ accession number P13010), and human Tbdn100 (GenBank accession number AY112670) were generated by PCR to introduce BamHI-XbaI linkers and ligated in contiguous open reading frames downstream of the Gal4 DNA binding domain in pFA-CMV. All eukaryotic Runx2 and Msx2 expression plasmids were prepared in pcDNA3 using techniques described previously (16Newberry E.P. Boudreaux J.M. Towler D.A. J. Biol. Chem. 1997; 272: 29607-29613Google Scholar). Isoform II of murine Runx2 (528 aa, MASN...; GenBank™ accession number AF005936) was used to reconstitute Runx2 signaling in naïve CV-1 cells. The following C-terminal truncation variants were prepared from Runx2 isoform II: Runx2 (1-412 aa) to remove the Runx2 C-terminal VWRPY repression domain; Runx2 (1-392) to remove the nuclear matrix targeting signal (NMTS); Runx2 (1-312) to remove Activation Domain 3 (AD3) and distal C-terminal sequences, and an internal deletion lacking AD3 in the context of full length Runx2-Runx2 (1-528; Δ308-375). To provide cell-autonomous FGFR2 stimulation, a plasmid coding for constitutively active FGF2 Receptor FGFR2-ROS (26Lorenzi M.V. Horii Y. Yamanaka R. Sakaguchi K. Miki T. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1996; 93: 8956-8961Google Scholar) was used in co-transfection experiments. The construction and characterization of OCFRE-LUC has been detailed previously (18Willis D.M. Loewy A.P. Charlton-Kachigian N. Shao J.S. Ornitz D.M. Towler D.A. J. Biol. Chem. 2002; 277: 37280-37291Google Scholar). The full-length mouse MINT cDNA was cloned by long PCR of reverse-transcribed mRNA from MC3T3E1 calvarial osteoblasts cells (21Newberry E.P. Latifi T. Towler D.A. Biochemistry. 1999; 38: 10678-10690Google Scholar). In brief, 2 μg of total RNA isolated from logarithmically growing MC3T3E1 cells was used in reverse transcription with Oligo d(T) primer and 200 units of Superscript II RT (Invitrogen). The reaction was carried out at 42 °C for 50 min, then diluted 5-fold with nuclease-free water. For PCR, 5 μL of the diluted RT reactions was used for PCR cloning of full-length MINT transcript. The amplimers used were 5′-CCG TGT CGA CCA TGG GAG ACC GAG ACC TCC GCA-3′ and 5′-GCA TGC GGC CGC TCA CAC CGA GGC AAT GAC AAT CAT-3′. PCR reactions were carried out in 50 μL containing 3.5 units of Expand high fidelity Roche polymerase (Roche Diagnostics). DNA was denatured for 3 min at 94 °C, then biphasic PCR carried out for 25 cycles (15 s at 94 °C, 11 min at 68 °C) to obtain a ∼11-kb amplicon that was subcloned into pGEM (Promega, Madison, WI). DNA sequencing and in vitro transcription-translation (TnT; Promega) of the subcloned fragment was used to verify expression of full-length MINT protein. The pGEM-MINT plasmid was digested with SalI and NotI, and the full-length MINT cDNA was ligated into pCMV-hemagglutinin tag vector (BD Biosciences Clontech) to make CMV-MINT(1-3576), denoted CMV-MINT or MINT. A similar strategy was used to make the variant CMV-MINT(734-3576), denoted CMV-MINT(ΔRRM) or MINT-ΔRRM. This latter variant construct retains the MINT mid region and C-terminal sequence downstream of an initiator Met, retains a subset of the nuclear localization cognates, and localizes to the nucleus (data not shown) but completely lacks intact N-terminal RRM domains (21Newberry E.P. Latifi T. Towler D.A. Biochemistry. 1999; 38: 10678-10690Google Scholar). For fluorescence imaging of Runx2 and Msx2, full-length cDNAs were cloned in a CMV-driven plasmid downstream of the EGFP coding sequence (Living Colors EGFP-C1 plasmid; BD Biosciences Clontech) to create EGFP-Runx2 and EGFP-Msx2, respectively. Cell Lines and Transfection—CV-1 fibroblasts and MC3T3E1 calvarial osteoblasts were grown as described previously (18Willis D.M. Loewy A.P. Charlton-Kachigian N. Shao J.S. Ornitz D.M. Towler D.A. J. Biol. Chem. 2002; 277: 37280-37291Google Scholar). Transfection by lipofection and luciferase reporter assays were carried out as detailed previously (18Willis D.M. Loewy A.P. Charlton-Kachigian N. Shao J.S. Ornitz D.M. Towler D.A. J. Biol. Chem. 2002; 277: 37280-37291Google Scholar), but using 24-well cluster dishes in lieu of 12-well cluster dishes. When indicated, treatment with 10 ng/ml FGF2 (human basic FGF2; BD Biosciences) was initiated 24 h before harvesting cells for luciferase activity. For confocal imaging, MC3T3E1 cells were plated in sterile four-chamber slides (Lab-Tek II; Nalge Nunc, Naperville, IL) and transfected the next day with 0.2 μg/well EGFP-Runx2 and 0.8 μg/well CMV-MINT plasmids using Superfect Reagent (Qiagen, Valencia, CA). After 3 h, transfection mix was removed, cells were rinsed with Dulbecco's modified Eagle's medium, and added fresh 1% fetal calf serum in Dulbecco's modified Eagle's medium. After 24 h, medium was changed again and half of the wells were treated with freshly prepared human FGF2 (10 ng/ml) or vehicle in 1% fetal calf serum in Dulbecco's modified Eagle's medium and incubated for 18 h. Immunostaining—Cells were fixed in 4% paraformaldehyde for 30 min and treated with ammonium chloride to neutralize unspecific cross-linking. Subsequently, cells were permeabilized with 0.1% Triton X-100 in PBS for 20 min and blocked with 1% bovine serum albumin in PBS for an additional 30 min. The rabbit anti-MINT “R1β” primary antibody against the central Msx2 interacting domain (21Newberry E.P. Latifi T. Towler D.A. Biochemistry. 1999; 38: 10678-10690Google Scholar) was then added at a 1:100 dilution in 1% bovine serum albumin-PBS for 1-4 h at room temperature, mixing in an orbital shaker. Cells were washed three times for 15 min each with 0.1% Triton X-100 in PBS. Secondary Cy3-conjugated or Alexa 647-conjugated goat anti-rabbit antibody (1:400) was then added in 1% bovine serum albumin-PBS and incubated for at least 1 h at room temperature in an orbital shaker. Cells were washed three times for 15 min each with 0.1% Triton X-100 in PBS before adding mounting media, placing a 0.15-mm thick coverslip, and sealing with nail polish. Slides were kept in the dark at 4 °C until analyzed. Confocal Microscopy and Deconvolution Analyses—Double-stained cells were imaged using a Bio-Rad Radiance 2000 confocal inverted microscope using 60× oil lens (numerical aperture, 1.4); an optimal pinhole aperture was used at all times, and at least three z-stack sections (every 0.48 μm) were acquired per cell. To avoid bleed-through, images were acquired using line-by-line strobe scanning and with lasers whose excitation/emission spectra do not overlap: argon (488 nm) for EGFP and red diode (647 nm) for MINT. For Cy3 imaging, green HeNe laser was used (543 nm). All images were deconvolved using the ‘single image constrained iter deconvolution algorithm’ at four iterations, with brightness set at 1.5 (Microtome 7.0; VayTek Software, Fairfield, IA). Images were acquired in grayscale, converted to pseudo-color, and merged using Image Pro-Plus Software (Media Cybernetics, Carlsbad, CA). MINT exhibits a reticular pattern, whereas Runx2 exhibits a partially overlapping punctuate pattern. To determine the proportion of Runx2 punctate foci that also had the signal for MINT, six high quality, deconvolved images were evaluated characterizing several adjacent cells in the field of view. The total numbers of Runx2 foci were digitally counted (n = 491 in cells treated with vehicle; n = 558 in cells treated with FGF2), and two independent observers counted the number of Runx2 foci stained for MINT (scored only if >50% overlap). Data were averaged and presented as the mean ± S.D. percentage of MINT-positive Runx2 foci. The non-parametric Kruskal-Wallis test on raw data sets was used to test statistical significance for differences in the number of Runx2 foci with MINT staining as a function of FGF2 treatment. Chromatin Immunoprecipitation Assays—ChIP assays were carried out essentially as described previously (18Willis D.M. Loewy A.P. Charlton-Kachigian N. Shao J.S. Ornitz D.M. Towler D.A. J. Biol. Chem. 2002; 277: 37280-37291Google Scholar), implementing a commercially available polyclonal antibody against the invariant C terminus of Runx2 (C-19; Santa Cruz Biotechnology, Santa Cruz, CA). MC3T3E1 cells, which express endogenous Runx2, were stably transfected with either pcDNA3 or pcDNA3-Msx2 as previously detailed. After transfection, cells selected with G418 for 3 days and then processed for chromatin immunoprecipitation essentially as described previously (18Willis D.M. Loewy A.P. Charlton-Kachigian N. Shao J.S. Ornitz D.M. Towler D.A. J. Biol. Chem. 2002; 277: 37280-37291Google Scholar). PCR primers used for OC ChIP were 5′-TAT GAG AGT TGG AGC CCA GTT TAT C-3′ and 5′-CCC TAG AGA CAA GAA CCC TAT GCA T-3′ directed to the mouse OC (OG2) proximal promoter (GenBank accession number U66848). As a control, the osteopontin promoter gene was amplified because it is not affected by Msx2 (14Bidder M. Latifi T. Towler D.A. J. Bone Miner. Res. 1998; 13: 609-619Google Scholar). Osteopontin genomic PCR primers were 5′-CAC AAA ACC AGA GGA GGA AGT GT-3′ and 5′-GGT CCA GAC AGT CTC CAC CAA-3′ directed against the murine OPN proximal promoter (GenBank™ accession number AY220127.1). PCR amplifications were observed in ethidium-stained polyacrylamide gels, captured digitally, and displayed as light-dark inverted images. In completely independent experimental sets, MC3T3E1 cells were transduced either with SFG-LacZ (control) or SFG-Msx2 retroviral expression vectors, generated and characterized as reported previously (12Cheng S.L. Shao J.S. Charlton-Kachigian N. Loewy A.P. Towler D.A. J. Biol. Chem. 2003; 278: 45969-45977Google Scholar). In this experiment, subconfluent cells were cultured for 1 week in 10% fetal calf serum in α-minimal essential medium with 50 μg/ml ascorbic acid. OC ChIP assays were performed and quantified by real-time fluorescence PCR with a GeneAmp 7700 Sequence Detection System (Applied Biosystems, Foster City, CA) as detailed previously (18Willis D.M. Loewy A.P. Charlton-Kachigian N. Shao J.S. Ornitz D.M. Towler D.A. J. Biol. Chem. 2002; 277: 37280-37291Google Scholar). Twenty nanograms of processed genomic DNA was used in each PCR reaction. The signal arising from 1 pg of mouse genomic DNA was used as a standard. Data were expressed as the mean picograms ± S.D. of OC genomic DNA equivalents present in the Runx2 immunoprecipitate from four independent cultures/precipitations for both SFG-LacZ and SFG-Msx2 cultures. RNA Interference and Fluorescence RT-PCR Analysis of OC mRNA—The siRNA duplexes against MINT were designed following Tuschl's principles (27Elbashir S.M. Harborth J. Lendeckel W. Yalcin A. Weber K. Tuschl T. Nature. 2001; 411: 494-498Google Scholar). To screen for silencing duplexes, we constructed a reporter MINT fusion protein, MINT-EGFP, by ligating the EGFP cDNA (derived by PCR from LivingColors vector; BD Biosciences Clontech) in a contiguous open reading frame using the unique BglII site in the MINT cDNA. Thus, the 36 C-terminal amino acids of MINT are replaced by EGFP in the MINT-EGFP fusion protein. To screen for active MINT siRNAs, synthetic 21-bp duplexes were cotransfected along MINT-EGFP into MC3T3-E1 cells using Mirrus TransIT-TKO reagent (Mirrus Co., Madison, WI) and evaluated by fluorescence microscopy 24 h later. In parallel, GFP-targeted siRNA was used as a positive control, and luciferase-directed siRNA was used as a negative control. Of the nine MINT-directed siRNA sequences designed and tested, an siRNA duplex against the MINT target sequence AAG CAG CAG GGA TTA TCA ATG reduced EGFP signal comparable with cells transfected with the GFP-targeted siRNA (positive control). This MINT-targeted siRNA duplex was chosen to evaluate the role of MINT on osteocalcin gene expression. In independent duplicate cultures, MC3T3-E1 cells were transfected with either 100 nm MINT-targeted siRNA or luciferase-targeted siRNA (negative control). The next day, MC3T3E1 cells were switched to osteogenic differentiation media (10% fetal calf serum in α-minimal essential medium, supplemented with 50 μg/ml ascorbic acid and 10 mm β-glycerol phosphate) and cultured for an additional 10 days. RNA was subsequently extracted, contaminating DNA was removed with DNaseI, and OC, OPN, and β-tubulin mRNA accumulation expression evaluated by fluorescent RT-PCR as described previously (18Willis D.M. Loewy A.P. Charlton-Kachigian N. Shao J.S. Ornitz D.M. Towler D.A. J. Biol. Chem. 2002; 277: 37280-37291Google Scholar, 28Shao J.S. Cheng S.L. Charlton-Kachigian N. Loewy A.P. Towler D.A. J. Biol. Chem. 2003; 278: 50195-50202Google Scholar). The experiment was repeated twice. Runx2 Provides a Major FGF2-Regulated Transactivation Function in the OCFRE Promoter Binding Complex—In the calvarial osteoblast, the OCFRE assembles a multiprotein complex containing Runx2 and a novel Ku-antigen transcription factor complex (18Willis D.M. Loewy A.P. Charlton-Kachigian N. Shao J.S. Ornitz D.M. Towler D.A. J. Biol. Chem. 2002; 277: 37280-37291Google Scholar). This complex is the target of both FGFR2-dependent activation and Msx2 suppression. To clarify which of these proteins may provide major transactivation functions versus structural function, we analyzed autonomous TAF in Gal4 one-hybrid analyses. As shown in Fig. 1A, among Ku70, Ku80, Tbdn100, and Runx2, only Runx2 exhibited major basal TAF activity when fused to the Gal4 DNA binding domain when using the Gal4 responsive luciferase reporter pFR-LUC. Importantly, the Runx2 TAF is regulated by FGFR2 signaling. Co-expression of the constitutively active FGFR2, FGFR2-ROS, enhances Runx2 TAF both in one-hybrid assays (Fig. 1A) and on the OCFRE (Fig. 1B). Because Runx2 provided the major basal and FGF-dependent transactivation function of the OCFRE binding factors, we sought to determine the part of Runx2 that was critical for FGF-dependent activation of the OCFRE. Using a series of C-terminally truncated Runx2 variants and the OCFRE-LUC reporter, we determined that the TAF domain regulated by FGFR2-ROS resides outside of t

FK506-binding protein 52 (FKBP52) is an immunophilin that possesses peptidylprolyl cis/trans-isomerase (PPIase) activity and is a component of a subclass of steroid hormone receptor complexes. Several recent studies indicate that immunophilins can regulate neuronal survival and nerve regeneration although the molecular mechanisms are poorly understood. To investigate the function of FKBP52 in the nervous system, we employed a yeast two-hybrid strategy using the PPIase domain (domain I) as bait to screen a neonatal rat dorsal root ganglia cDNA expression library. We identified an interaction between FKBP52 domain I and Atox1, a copper-binding metallochaperone. Atox1 interacts with Menkes disease protein and Wilson disease protein (WD) and functions in copper efflux. The interaction between FKBP52 and Atox1 was observed in both glutathione S-transferase pull-down experiments and when proteins were ectopically expressed in human embryonic kidney (HEK) 293T cells and was sensitive to FK506. Interestingly, the FKBP52/Atox1 interaction was enhanced when HEK 293T cells were cultured in copper-supplemented medium and decreased in the presence of the copper chelator, bathocuproine disulfate, suggesting that the interaction is regulated in part by intracellular copper. Overexpression of FKBP52 increased rapid copper efflux in 64Cu-loaded cells, as did the overexpression of WD transporter. Taken together, our present findings suggest that FKBP52 is a component of the copper efflux machinery, and in so, may also promote neuroprotection from copper toxicity. FK506-binding protein 52 (FKBP52) is an immunophilin that possesses peptidylprolyl cis/trans-isomerase (PPIase) activity and is a component of a subclass of steroid hormone receptor complexes. Several recent studies indicate that immunophilins can regulate neuronal survival and nerve regeneration although the molecular mechanisms are poorly understood. To investigate the function of FKBP52 in the nervous system, we employed a yeast two-hybrid strategy using the PPIase domain (domain I) as bait to screen a neonatal rat dorsal root ganglia cDNA expression library. We identified an interaction between FKBP52 domain I and Atox1, a copper-binding metallochaperone. Atox1 interacts with Menkes disease protein and Wilson disease protein (WD) and functions in copper efflux. The interaction between FKBP52 and Atox1 was observed in both glutathione S-transferase pull-down experiments and when proteins were ectopically expressed in human embryonic kidney (HEK) 293T cells and was sensitive to FK506. Interestingly, the FKBP52/Atox1 interaction was enhanced when HEK 293T cells were cultured in copper-supplemented medium and decreased in the presence of the copper chelator, bathocuproine disulfate, suggesting that the interaction is regulated in part by intracellular copper. Overexpression of FKBP52 increased rapid copper efflux in 64Cu-loaded cells, as did the overexpression of WD transporter. Taken together, our present findings suggest that FKBP52 is a component of the copper efflux machinery, and in so, may also promote neuroprotection from copper toxicity. FKBP52 1The abbreviations used are: FKBP52, FK506-binding protein 52; PPIase, peptidylpropyl cis-trans-isomerase; TPR, tetratricopeptide repeat; HSP90, heat shock protein 90; DRG, dorsal root ganglia; MNK, Menkes disease protein; WD, Wilson disease protein; GST, glutathione S-transferase; X-gal, 5-bromo-4-chloro-3-indolyl-β-d-galactopyranoside; BCS, bathocuproine disulfate; PBS, phosphate-buffered saline. is a high molecular weight FK506-binding immunophilin first identified as a component of steroid hormone receptor heterocomplexes (1Tai P.K. Maeda Y. Nakao K. Wakim N.G. Duhring J.L. Faber L.E. Biochemistry. 1986; 25: 5269-5275Crossref PubMed Scopus (189) Google Scholar). Analysis of mRNA and protein levels has demonstrated that FKBP52 is widely expressed in mammalian tissues but particularly abundant in the nervous system (2Steiner J.P. Dawson T.M. Fotuhi M. Glatt C.E. Snowman A.M. Cohen N. Snyder S.H. Nature. 1992; 358: 584-587Crossref PubMed Scopus (325) Google Scholar, 3Nair S.C. Rimerman R.A. Toran E.J. Chen S. Prapapanich V. Butts R.N. Smith D.F. Mol. Cell. Biol. 1997; 17: 594-603Crossref PubMed Scopus (168) Google Scholar). Structurally, FKBP52 contains an N-terminal peptidylprolyl cis-trans-isomerase (PPIase) domain (domain I), a FKBP-like pseudo domain (domain II), three tetratricopeptide repeat (TPR) domains (domain III) that mediate proteinprotein interactions with HSP90, and a C-terminal domain calmodulin-binding site (domain IV) (4Li P. Ding Y. Wu B. Shu C. Shen B. Rao Z. Acta Crystallogr. D. Biol. Crystallogr. 2003; 59: 16-22Crossref PubMed Scopus (28) Google Scholar, 5Wu B. Li P. Shu C. Shen B. Rao Z. Acta Crystallogr. D. Biol. Crystallogr. 2003; 59: 2269-2271Crossref PubMed Scopus (6) Google Scholar). FKBP52 has been shown to play important roles in a diverse number of intracellular processes, but much research has focused on its involvement in steroid hormone regulation. FKBP52 regulates the maturation of steroid hormone receptor complexes through interactions between its TPR domain and HSP90 chaperones, which act as scaffolds for receptor assembly and are thought to enhance the affinity of estrogen receptor and the glucocorticoid receptor toward their ligands (1Tai P.K. Maeda Y. Nakao K. Wakim N.G. Duhring J.L. Faber L.E. Biochemistry. 1986; 25: 5269-5275Crossref PubMed Scopus (189) Google Scholar, 6Smith D.F. Baggenstoss B.A. Marion T.N. Rimerman R.A. J. Biol. Pratt W.B. J. Biol. Chem. 2001; 276: 14884-14889Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (196) Google Scholar). Immunity. 2000; 12: 129-140Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (81) Google Scholar) and heat-shock factor-1 in HeLa cells (9Guo Y. Guettouche T. Fenna M. Boellmann F. Pratt W.B. Toft D.O. Smith D.F. Voellmy R. J. Biol. Chem. 2001; 276: 45791-45799Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (169) Google Scholar). FKBP52 has been implicated in the cardiotrophic effect of cardiotrophin-1 (10Railson J.E. Lawrence K. Buddle J.C. Pennica D. Latchman D.S. J. Mol. Cell. Cardiol. 2001; 33: 1209-1221Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (13) Google Scholar) and in regulating the efficiency of adenoassociated virus type 2-mediated transgene expression (11Qing K. Hansen J. Weigel-Kelley K.A. Tan M. Zhou S. Srivastava A. J. Virol. 2001; 75: 8968-8976Crossref PubMed Scopus (112) Google Scholar). Over the past decade, there has been growing interest to understand the role of immunophilin, or neuroimmunophilins, in the nervous system (13Sharkey J. Butcher S.P. Nature. 1994; 371: 336-339Crossref PubMed Scopus (440) Google Scholar, 14Gold B.G. Austin D.R. Storm-Dickerson T. Neurosci. Lett. 1994; 176: 123-127Crossref PubMed Scopus (22) Google Scholar). Fischer G. Sartor K. Herdegen T. Neuroscience. 2003; 120: 1037-1048Crossref PubMed Scopus (39) Google Scholar). Neurol. 2003; 183: 220-231Crossref PubMed Scopus (83) Google Scholar) and derivatives V-10,367 (17Gold B.G. Zeleny-Pooley M. Wang M.S. Chaturvedi P. Armistead D.M. Exp. Neurol. 1997; 147: 269-278Crossref PubMed Scopus (138) Google Scholar), GPI-1046 (18Steiner J.P. Connolly M.A. Valentine H.L. Hamilton G.S. Dawson T.M. Hester L. Snyder S.H. Nat. Med. 1997; 3: 421-428Crossref PubMed Scopus (323) Google Scholar), and JNJ-460 (19Birge R.B. Wadsworth S. Akakura R. Abeysinghe H. Kanojia R. MacIelag M. Desbarats J. Escalante M. Singh K. Sundarababu S. Parris K. Childs G. August A. Siekierka J. Weinstein D.E. Presently, however, little is known about the mechanisms by which immunophilins regulate cell signaling and neuroprotection. In the present study, we employed a yeast two-hybrid screen to identify proteins that physically and/or functionally interact with FKBP52. Using a dorsal root ganglia (DRG) expression library and FKBP domain I as “bait” we found that FKBP52 interacts with Atox1, a metallochaperone that transfers copper to Menkes Disease Protein (MNK) and Wilson Disease Protein (WD) (20Hamza I. Schaefer M. Klomp L.W. Gitlin J.D. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1999; 96: 13363-13368Crossref PubMed Scopus (241) Google Scholar). Whereas previous studies have shown that immunophilins can effect calcium metabolism and regulate calcium channels (21Cameron A.M. Steiner J.P. Sabatini D.M. Kaplin A.I. Walensky L.D. Snyder S.H. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1995; 92: 1784-1788Crossref PubMed Scopus (269) Google Scholar, 22Timerman A.P. Wiederrecht G. Marcy A. Fleischer S. J. Biol. Chem. 1995; 270: 2451-2459Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (129) Google Scholar), our present data show for the first time that FKBP52 is implicated in the copper efflux machinery in mammalian cells. Materials—Radiochemical pure (>97%) 64Cu was provided by Debbie Sultan (Mallinckrodt Institute of Radiology, Washington University Medical School). Commercially available antibodies were purchased from their respective vendors: anti-V5 antibody (Invitrogen), anti-FLAG antibody (Sigma), and anti-GST antibody (Santa Cruz Biotechnology). The yeast strains EGY48, pEG202, p8op-lacZ, and p2op-lacZ were purchased from Clontech, as part of Matchmaker™ library cloning reagents. Yeast Two-hybrid Screen—A P1 to P3 neonatal rat DRG cDNA expression library inserted into the DNA activation domain pB42AD vector was kindly provided by Dr. Moses Chao (The Skirball Institute, New York University). Briefly, FKBP52 domain I (amino acids 32–138) containing the entire PPIase domain was inserted into the DNA binding domain of pEG202 vector in the correct reading frame and stable transformants selected in the yeast strain EGY48. To isolate FKBP52 domain I (FKBP52I)-interacting cDNAs, EGY48 expressing pEG202-FKBP52I and p8op-lacZ was transformed with the rat DRG cDNA library and plated on SD/Gal/Raf/-His/-Trp/-Leu/-Ura medium with 8 μg/ml X-gal. Replicate experiments were conducted in the presence of 10 nm FK506 to identify potential gain of function mutants. The blue colonies were streaked three times on the -Trp SD medium to remove non-library containing plasmids. Plasmids from X-gal positive colonies stained blue color were confirmed and DNA was isolated and sequenced using the dideoxy termination method. Expression Vector, Transfection, Immunoprecipitation, and Western Blotting—pcDNA-V5-FKBP52 (GenBank™ accession number M88279), containing an V5 epitope tag at the C terminus, was purchased from Invitrogen. Full-length FKBP52 or FKBP52 domain I fragment (amino acids 32–152) was subcloned by PCR into pcDNA or pFLAG for mammalian expression, pGEX-6P1 for recombinant expression in DH5α bacteria as a GST fusion protein. pcDNA-WD was a generous gift from Dr. J. Gitlin (Washington University School of Medicine). Transient overexpression was achieved using LipofectAMINE™ method, according to the manufacturer's instructions. Briefly, HEK 293T cells were co-transfected with expression plasmids as indicated in the manuscript. After 48 h, cells were lysed in 1% HNTG buffer (20 mm HEPES, pH 7.5, 150 mm NaCl, 1% Triton X-100, 10% glycerol) containing 1 mm phenylmethylsulfonyl fluoride, 1 mm sodium vanadate, and 20 μg/ml aprotinin. For immunoprecipitation, up to 1.0 mg of total cellular protein was incubated with primary antibody for 2 h at 4 °C, followed by incubation with protein A-Sepharose for 1 h at 4 °C, then resolved by SDS-PAGE. Western blotting was performed following SDS-PAGE and transfer to polyvinylidene difluoride membranes (Millipore). Blots were incubated with primary antibodies, diluted in 5% milk, after which the blots were washed in Tris-buffered saline containing 0.05% Tween 20 and subsequently incubated with horseradish peroxidase-conjugated secondary antibodies. Immunoblots were developed with an enhanced chemiluminescence kit (Western Lightning; PerkinElmer Life Sciences). Metabolic Labeling and Copper Measurements—HEK 293T cells were maintained in Dulbecco's modified Eagle's medium supplemented with 10% fetal bovine serum at 37 °C in a humidified atmosphere containing 5% CO2. The copper efflux experiment was employed as described by Hamza et al. (23Hamza I. Faisst A. Prohaska J. Chen J. Gruss P. Gitlin J.D. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 2001; 98: 6848-6852Crossref PubMed Scopus (174) Google Scholar). For copper efflux studies, 2 × 105 HEK 293T cells were allowed to adhere onto 24 well plate and 8 × 106 cpm of 64Cu cells were premixed with 200 μm copper (chloride salt) and 400 μm l-histidine (Sigma) for 1 h at 37 °C in serum-free Opti-MEM (Invitrogen). Cells were pulsed with 200 μm64Cu for 1 h as described above, followed by free quick rinses with prewarmed PBS to remove any residual copper and then incubated with prewarmed Opti-MEM alone for several chase period. Cells were washed three times with ice-cold PBS, lysed with PBS containing 1% SDS, and analyzed for 64Cu retention by using scintillation counting. To examine the effect of FK506, cells were treated with drug for 2 h before pulse with 200 μm64Cu and for 1 h during pulse. To investigate the function of FKBP52 in the nervous system, we employed a yeast two-hybrid strategy using the PPIase domain (domain I; residues 32–138 fused to the DNA-binding domain of LexA) as bait to screen a neonatal rat DRG expression cDNA library (Fig. 1A). The yeast strain EGY48, containing LexA-responsive reporter genes LEU2 and lacZ under the control of two or eight LexA binding sites, was used to assay the interactions. Among His+ clones, those found to display β-galactosidase activity were rescued from each of these clones and used for retransformation of the reporter strain in combination with pLexA-FKBP52-domain I under higher stringency (p2op-lacZ reporter). Based on AluI restriction enzyme mapping (data not shown) and partial sequence analysis, three cDNA clones were purified and terminally sequenced, two of which were identified by computer-assisted sequence homology search with the GenBank™ data base. One cDNA clone of 503 bp corresponded to the metallochaperone Atox1 (GenBank™ accession number NM053359), a 9-kDa protein involved in transporting copper to the MNK and WD, ATPase 7A/7B transporters (20Hamza I. Schaefer M. Klomp L.W. Gitlin J.D. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1999; 96: 13363-13368Crossref PubMed Scopus (241) Google Scholar). The second cDNA was identified as the actin capping protein Advillin (24Marks P.W. Arai M. Bandura J.L. Kwiatkowski D.J. J. Cell Sci. 1998; 111: 2129-2136Crossref PubMed Google Scholar), and the third clone of 0.6 kbp had a unique nucleotide sequence and was not studied further. Both Advillin and Atox1 were identified in multiple clones (Fig. 1B). Replicate screens were conducted in the presence of 10 nm FK506 in an attempt to isolate FKBP52 gain of function effectors, but only the three aforementioned clones were identified (data not shown). To determine the effect of FK506 on the interaction of FKBP52 with Atox1, β-galactosidase activity was measured using increasing concentration of FK506 in liquid culture assays. As shown in Fig. 1C, excess FK506 significantly decreased β-galactosidase activity, consistent with the data indicating that the domain I of FKBP52 mediates the interaction between FKBP52 and Atox1. To confirm the association of FKBP52 domain I with Atox1 in vitro, cell lysates from expressing FLAG-tagged Atox1 HEK 293T cells were incubated with GST, full-length GST-FKBP52 and GST-FKBP52 domain I (Fig. 2A). GST complexes were washed extensively and analyzed by Western blotting with anti-FLAG antibody. As indicated in the GST pull-down experiment, Atox1 specifically bound to both GST-FKBP52 and GST-FKBP52 domain I (Fig. 2A), suggesting that the C-terminal domain does not influence the interaction in vitro. To determine the relevance of the Atox1-FKBP52 interaction in mammalian cells, HEK 293T cells were co-transfected with full-length V5 epitope-tagged FKBP52 and FLAG epitope-tagged Atox1. Immunoprecipitation of V5-FKBP52 complexes contained Atox1 when analyzed by Western blot (Fig. 2B). This interaction was confirmed by conversely immunoprecipitating FLAG-Atox1 complexes and identifying V5-FKBP52 (data not shown). To assess whether the FKBP52 and Atox1 interaction is dependent on copper, cultured HEK cell expressing FKBP52 and Atox1 were exposed to increasing concentrations of copper-supplemented media or in the presence of the copper chelator, BCS. As shown in Fig. 2C, increasing the extracellular copper resulted in a dose-dependent increased in co-immunoprecipitated Atox1 and FKBP52, and conversely, chelation of extracellular copper with BCS decreased the interaction. These studies suggest that the interaction between FKBP52 and Atox1 may depend on intracellular levels and possible functions as a stress response to increased cellular copper. In both the aforementioned systems, increased amounts of FK506 partially blocked the interaction (Fig. 2D and not shown). Analogous to other immunophilin-binding proteins, including binding of FKBP12 to the ryanodine receptors I and II (25Gaburjakova M. Gaburjakova J. Reiken S. Huang F. Marx S.O. Rosemblit N. Marks A.R. J. Biol. Chem. 2001; 276: 16931-16935Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (140) Google Scholar), inositol 1,4,5-trisphosphate receptor (26Cameron A.M. Nucifora Jr., F.C. Fung E.T. Livingston D.J. Aldape R.A. Ross C.A. Snyder S.H. J. Biol. Chem. 1997; 272: 27582-27588Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (193) Google Scholar), and FKBP52 binding to the TRP channels (12Goel M. Garcia R. Estacion M. Schilling W.P. J. Biol. Chem. 2001; 276: 38762-38773Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (61) Google Scholar), Atox1 also contains an LP duet in the C termini (DIDLPNKKVC) that may direct binding to the FKBP domain. We propose that the LP motif may recruit FKBP52 to Atox1 and subsequently assist in the transfer of copper from Atox1 to MNK and WD possibly through a conformation change in the Atox1/MNK (or WD) complex. Normal copper homeostasis is maintained primarily by the liver where dietary copper is excreted to the bile or secreted into circulation as ceruloplasmin for tissue uptake (27Tapiero H. Townsend D.M. Tew K.D. Biomed. Pharmacother. 2003; 57: 386-398Crossref PubMed Scopus (716) Google Scholar). Intracellular copper homeostasis is maintained largely by proteins responsible for copper efflux, the copper-transporting MNK and WD, (ATPase7A/7B), as well as Atox1 (20Hamza I. Schaefer M. Klomp L.W. Gitlin J.D. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1999; 96: 13363-13368Crossref PubMed Scopus (241) Google Scholar). When cytoplasmic copper concentrations reach potentially toxic levels, MNK and WD redistribute from the trans-Golgi network to the plasma membrane facilitating the efflux of excess copper (20Hamza I. Schaefer M. Klomp L.W. Gitlin J.D. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1999; 96: 13363-13368Crossref PubMed Scopus (241) Google Scholar, 28Hamza I. Prohaska J. Gitlin J.D. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 2003; 100: 1215-1220Crossref PubMed Scopus (144) Google Scholar). To ascertain whether FKBP52 has an effect on copper efflux, we examined 64Cu retention in HEK 293T cells transfected with FKBP52. Prior to analysis, cells were metabolically labeled with 64Cu tracer and subsequently assessed for 64Cu efflux by measuring the retention of intracellular copper (23Hamza I. Faisst A. Prohaska J. Chen J. Gruss P. Gitlin J.D. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 2001; 98: 6848-6852Crossref PubMed Scopus (174) Google Scholar). As shown in Fig. 3, copper retention patterns showed a biphasic efflux pattern in which copper efflux is rapid in the first 5 min and slows after 10 min, consistent with reports of Hamza et al. (23Hamza I. Faisst A. Prohaska J. Chen J. Gruss P. Gitlin J.D. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 2001; 98: 6848-6852Crossref PubMed Scopus (174) Google Scholar). Interestingly, the rapid copper efflux (<5 min) was potentiated in FKBP52-expressing cells relative to vector-transfected cells and steady state plateau levels remained lower after 20 min following the chase (Fig. 3A). Similar kinetics of 64Cu efflux was noted following transfection with an expression plasmid encoding WD, ATPase7B (Fig. 3B). These data are consistent with a report showing that the overexpression of MNK permit Chinese hamster ovary cells to tolerate highly toxic amounts of copper in their immediate environment (29Camakaris J. Petris M.J. Bailey L. Shen P. Lockhart P. Glover T.W. Barcroft C. Patton J. Mercer J.F. Hum. Mol. Genet. 1995; 4: 2117-2123Crossref PubMed Scopus (157) Google Scholar) and also suggest that FKBP52 is functionally as well as biochemically linked to the Atox1/MNK (or WD) pathway. 100 nm FK506 pretreatment reproducibly blocked the early phase copper efflux in FKBP52 expressed cells (Fig. 3C). Although FKBP52 could conceivably effect copper by regulating the transfer of copper from apo-Atox1 to Cu-Atox1, studies by Hamza and colleagues (28Hamza I. Prohaska J. Gitlin J.D. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 2003; 100: 1215-1220Crossref PubMed Scopus (144) Google Scholar) showed that when intracellular copper levels are increased, Cu-MNK (or WD) proteins are rapid redistribution from the trans-Golgi. These data indicate that the transport of copper from Atox1 to MNK (or WD) can be positively regulated and possibly requires the chaperone function of FKBP52. Copper is an essential component of several biological systems but can be toxic if not properly regulated (27Tapiero H. Townsend D.M. Tew K.D. Biomed. Pharmacother. 2003; 57: 386-398Crossref PubMed Scopus (716) Google Scholar). In humans, disruption of the tightly regulated cellular copper homeostasis affects normal tissue development and leads to anemia, neutropenia, cancer, and several neurodegenerative diseases (27Tapiero H. Townsend D.M. Tew K.D. Biomed. Pharmacother. 2003; 57: 386-398Crossref PubMed Scopus (716) Google Scholar). Menkes disease is caused by recessive deletions in the ATP7A gene (MNK protein), a phenotype associated with overall copper deficiency due to impaired export of intestinal cells (30Lutsenko S. Petris M.J. J. Membr. Biol. 2003; 191: 1-12Crossref PubMed Scopus (176) Google Scholar). Wilson disease, in contrast, is caused by copper accumulation predominantly in liver, brain, and kidney as a result of mutants in the ATP7B gene (WD protein) (31Muller T. van de Sluis B. Muller W. Pearson P. Wijmenga C. Eur. J. Med. Res. 1999; 4: 293-297PubMed Google Scholar). The phenotype of Atox1 null mice recapitulate many of the characteristics of MNK and WD deficiencies, including the accumulation of intracellular copper and perinatal lethality (23Hamza I. Faisst A. Prohaska J. Chen J. Gruss P. Gitlin J.D. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 2001; 98: 6848-6852Crossref PubMed Scopus (174) Google Scholar). Consistent with this idea, overexpression of Atox1 in neuronal cells protects cells from oxidative stress and apoptosis by increasing copper efflux. Recent studies also show that forced overexpression of MNK also reduced intracellular copper levels and down-regulated amyloid-β precursor protein expression (32Bellingham S.A. Lahiri D.K. Maloney B. La Fontaine S. Multhaup G. Camakaris J. J. Biol. Chem. 2004; 279: 20378-20386Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (148) Google Scholar). Human central nervous system diseases associated with defects in metal metabolism include Menkes and Wilson disease (30Lutsenko S. Petris M.J. J. Membr. Biol. 2003; 191: 1-12Crossref PubMed Scopus (176) Google Scholar, 31Muller T. van de Sluis B. Muller W. Pearson P. Wijmenga C. Eur. J. Med. Res. 1999; 4: 293-297PubMed Google Scholar), and many studies now indicate that alterations in metal homeostasis may contribute to Alzheimer's disease, amyotrophic lateral sclerosis, Parkinson's disease, and Prion disease (27Tapiero H. Townsend D.M. Tew K.D. Biomed. Pharmacother. 2003; 57: 386-398Crossref PubMed Scopus (716) Google Scholar). Future studies that recapitulate the copper efflux activity of FKBP52 may have therapeutic value. We thank Jonathan D. Gitlin (Washington University School of Medicine) for the Wilson Disease Protein expression plasmid (pcDNA-WD) and Moses Chao (The Skirball Institute, New York University) for the DRG library. We thank Junji Magae (Institute of Research and Innovation, Chiba, Japan) for critical reading of the manuscript. The production of 64Cu at Washington University School of Medicine is supported by the NCI, National Institutes of Health Grant R24 CA86307.

Smad proteins are central mediators of the transforming growth factor-β (TGF-β) superfamily signaling. The mitogen-activated protein kinase (MAPK) p38 is also one of the downstream targets required for TGF-β-mediated responses. Although the interplay between the p38 and Smad signaling pathways might allow cells to display diverse patterns of responses to TGF-β, the mechanism of this cross-talk is not well established. We report here that inhibition of the p38α isoform suppressed the ability of Smad3 to mediate TGF-β-induced transcriptional responses. The inhibition of p38 activity blocked TGF-β-mediated phosphorylation of the MSK1 kinase, a substrate of p38 that plays an important role in the remodeling of chromatin. Moreover, we observed that expression of dominant-interfering mutants of MSK1 blocked the binding of Smad3 to the coactivator p300 in response to TGF-β signaling. These data reveal a new mechanism whereby the Smad signaling pathway and the p38 cascade are integrated in the nucleus to activate gene expression. Smad proteins are central mediators of the transforming growth factor-β (TGF-β) superfamily signaling. The mitogen-activated protein kinase (MAPK) p38 is also one of the downstream targets required for TGF-β-mediated responses. Although the interplay between the p38 and Smad signaling pathways might allow cells to display diverse patterns of responses to TGF-β, the mechanism of this cross-talk is not well established. We report here that inhibition of the p38α isoform suppressed the ability of Smad3 to mediate TGF-β-induced transcriptional responses. The inhibition of p38 activity blocked TGF-β-mediated phosphorylation of the MSK1 kinase, a substrate of p38 that plays an important role in the remodeling of chromatin. Moreover, we observed that expression of dominant-interfering mutants of MSK1 blocked the binding of Smad3 to the coactivator p300 in response to TGF-β signaling. These data reveal a new mechanism whereby the Smad signaling pathway and the p38 cascade are integrated in the nucleus to activate gene expression. The transforming growth factor-β (TGF-β) 1The abbreviations used are: TGF-β, transforming growth factor-β; AF, dominant negative p38 mutant that cannot be phosphorylated; CBP, CREB-binding protein; CKD, C-terminal kinase dead; CREB, cAMP-response element-binding protein; EGFP, enhanced green fluorescent protein; ERK, extracellular signal-regulated kinase; GFP, green fluorescent protein; JNK, c-Jun N-terminal kinase; MAPK, mitogenactivated protein kinase; MDCK, Madin-Darby canine kidney; MKK, mitogen-activated protein kinase kinase; MSK, mitogen- and stress-activated protein kinase; MOPS, 4-morpholinepropanesulfonic acid; NKD, N-terminal kinase dead; PAI, plasminogen activator inhibitor; TβRI and TβRII, TGF-β type I receptor and type II receptor, respectively; WT, wild type.1The abbreviations used are: TGF-β, transforming growth factor-β; AF, dominant negative p38 mutant that cannot be phosphorylated; CBP, CREB-binding protein; CKD, C-terminal kinase dead; CREB, cAMP-response element-binding protein; EGFP, enhanced green fluorescent protein; ERK, extracellular signal-regulated kinase; GFP, green fluorescent protein; JNK, c-Jun N-terminal kinase; MAPK, mitogenactivated protein kinase; MDCK, Madin-Darby canine kidney; MKK, mitogen-activated protein kinase kinase; MSK, mitogen- and stress-activated protein kinase; MOPS, 4-morpholinepropanesulfonic acid; NKD, N-terminal kinase dead; PAI, plasminogen activator inhibitor; TβRI and TβRII, TGF-β type I receptor and type II receptor, respectively; WT, wild type. is a multifunctional factor that regulates a variety of cellular processes, including proliferation, apoptosis, extracellular matrix production, and differentiation (1Roberts A.B. Miner. Electrolyte Metab. 1998; 24: 111-119Crossref PubMed Scopus (336) Google Scholar). Binding of TGF-β to the TGF-β type II receptor (TβRII) triggers heterodimerization and transphosphorylation of the TGF-β type I receptor (TβRI). The signal is then propagated through phosphorylation of receptor-regulated Smads (R-Smads), Smad2 and Smad3, which oligomerize with the common mediator (Co-Smad) Smad4. The complexes then translocate to the nucleus, where they induce the expression of a large number of target genes via direct DNA binding or by association with other DNA-binding proteins (2Massague J. Wotton D. EMBO J. 2000; 19: 1745-1754Crossref PubMed Google Scholar, 3Moustakas A. Souchelnytskyi S. Heldin C.H. J. Cell Sci. 2001; 114: 4359-4369Crossref PubMed Google Scholar). The ability of Smads to modulate transcription in response to TGF-β also results from a functional cooperativity with general transcription coactivators such as CBP/p300.A growing body of evidence indicates that Smad signaling alone cannot account for the large diversity of effects of TGF-β, pointing toward other signaling pathways downstream of the TGF-β receptor that may contribute to the specificity of TGF-β action. The best characterized of these are the mitogen-activated protein kinases (MAPKs), including the extracellular signal-regulated kinases (ERKs), c-Jun N-terminal kinases (JNKs), and p38 kinases (4Mulder K.M. Cytokine Growth Factor Rev. 2000; 11: 23-35Crossref PubMed Scopus (383) Google Scholar, 5Yue J. Mulder K.M. Methods Mol. Biol. 2000; 142: 125-131PubMed Google Scholar). The effects of TGF-β on ERK, JNK, and p38 vary in kinetics and magnitude, but the biological consequences of MAPK activations are not totally understood. In addition to TGF-β, the p38 MAPK pathway is activated by different stimuli such as UV, heat shock, or osmotic misbalance that are involved in the mediation of apoptosis (6Ono K. Han J. Cell. Signal. 2000; 12: 1-13Crossref PubMed Scopus (1382) Google Scholar). As highlighted by recent studies, we can distinguish four isoforms of p38 (α, β, γ, and δ) in terms of specificity and physiological relevance (7Hale K.K. Trollinger D. Rihanek M. Manthey C.L. J. Immunol. 1999; 162: 4246-4252PubMed Google Scholar). For example, p38β is 180-fold more potent in activating AP1 than p38α (16Pramanik R. Qi X. Borowicz S. Choubey D. Schultz R.M. Han J. Chen G. J. Biol. Chem. 2003; 278: 4831-4839Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (125) Google Scholar). Besides its capacity to phosphorylate and activate transcription factors, p38 activates different kinases such as MSK1, which in turn transduces some downstream effects of p38 (8Deak M. Clifton A.D. Lucocq L.M. Alessi D.R. EMBO J. 1998; 17: 4426-4441Crossref PubMed Scopus (842) Google Scholar). The MSK1 kinase consists of an N-terminal and a C-terminal catalytic domain, and the activity of both domains is required for function of the protein (8Deak M. Clifton A.D. Lucocq L.M. Alessi D.R. EMBO J. 1998; 17: 4426-4441Crossref PubMed Scopus (842) Google Scholar). MSK1 is constitutively localized in the nucleus, where it interacts with the general transcription activators CBP/p300 (9Janknecht R. Oncogene. 2003; 22: 746-755Crossref PubMed Scopus (83) Google Scholar).Although the requirement of p300/CBP for the transcriptional activation of Smad-responsive genes is well established, the precise mechanism of action of these coactivators as well as the implication of other TGF-β-activated pathways in these processes is not well understood. In the present work, we demonstrate that the p38α isoform is activated by TGF-β and that this isoform is required for Smad-driven gene transcription. Our results also indicate that this function of p38 is mediated through the kinase MSK1, which regulates the formation of the Smad3-p300 complexes in response to TGF-β signaling. These findings reveal a novel mechanism for regulating Smad-dependent transcription by the p38 kinase pathway.EXPERIMENTAL PROCEDURESReagents—Recombinant human TGF-β1 and recombinant IFNα were purchased from Sigma, and the p38 inhibitor SB203580 was purchased from Calbiochem.Vectors—The luciferase reporter plasmids p3TP-Lux and (CAGA)9-Lux were kindly provided by Drs. J. Massague and J. M. Gauthier, respectively. The AP1-Lux plasmid was purchased from Stratagene. The AFs are p38 mutants that cannot be phosphorylated because TGY dual phosphorylation sites have been changed to AGF. The expression vectors pCMV5-FLAG MSK1 WT and MSK1 dead kinase (MSK1 C-terminal kinase dead (CKD) and MSK1 N-terminal kinase dead (NKD)) were gifts from Dr. D. Alessi. Vector coding for the FLAG-p300 fragment (1734–2464) was a generous gift from Dr. R. Janknecht. Biol. 2001; 21: 3302-3313Crossref PubMed Scopus (35) Google Scholar). The expression vectors encoding the constitutively activated forms of the MKK3 and MKK6 kinases (MKK3.E and MKK6.E) have been described previously (11Schrantz N. Bourgeade M.F. Mouhamad S. Leca G. Sharma S. Vazquez A. Mol. Biol. Cell. 2001; 12: 3139-3151Crossref PubMed Scopus (76) Google Scholar). The expression vector pEGFP-Smad3 was constructed using the pEGFP vector and Smad3 cDNA from pGEX-Smad3 (a gift from R. Derynck).Cell Culture and Transfections—The Burkitt lymphoma cells BL41 were maintained in RPMI medium containing 10% fetal calf serum. Cells were transfected with the different vectors by electroporation at 0.24 kV, 960 microfarads using a Bio-Rad apparatus. MDCK and COS7 cells were maintained in Dulbecco's modified medium containing 10% fetal calf serum. Cells were transfected with the different vectors by the LipofectAMINE method (Invitrogen) as described previously. Transfection efficiencies were normalized on the basis of β-galactosidase expression from pCMV5.LacZ-control vector. β-Galactosidase activity was measured using a luminescent Galacto-Star™ assay system (Applied Biosystems).Reverse Transcription-PCR—Total cellular RNA was isolated using the RNeasy kit (Quiagen) according to the manufacturer's instructions. The first strand of cDNA was made by reverse transcription of 2 μg of total RNA using (dT)-oligomer nucleotides. PCR was performed with upstream primer 5′-CCTTCTACCACGACGACTCA-3′ and downstream primer 5′-GGTGTCACGTGGTTCATCTT-3′ from the JunB sequence. PCR products were separated by electrophoresis on 1.8% agarose gels and visualized with ethidium bromide staining.Western Blot Analysis—Cells were lysed in 20 mm Tris (pH 7.4) and 0.5% SDS in the presence of 10 units of Benzon nuclease for 5 min at room temperature and boiled for 3 min. Total cell lysates were subjected to SDS-PAGE and electrophoretically transferred into nitrocellulose filters. Western blotting was performed with antiphospho-Smad3 (a generous gift from P. ten Dijke), antihemagglutinin, anti-FLAG and anti-Myc (Sigma), anti-JunB, anti-PAI-1 (anti-plasminogen activator inhibitor-1), anti-MSK1 and anti-p38α (Santa Cruz Biotechnology), antiphospho-MSK1 (Thr-581), antiphospho-MSK1 (Ser-376), antiphospho-MSK1 (Ser-360) (Cell Signaling Technology), and p38β (Upstate Biotechnologies) antibodies. Blots were revealed with sheep anti-mouse or anti-rabbit IgG horseradish peroxidase-linked antibodies and chemiluminescence (West Pico or West Femto, Pierce) using a DDC camera (LAS-1000, Fuji).Gene Reporter Assays—Cells were transfected with the different reporter genes by the electroporation method before being incubated in the absence or presence of TGF-β (0.2–1 ng/ml) for 18 h. Extracts were then prepared for luciferase assay following the instructions of the manufacturer (Promega).Protein Kinase Assay—MSK1 kinase activity was determined as described by Atfi et al. (19Atfi A. Djelloul S. Chastre E. Davis R. Gespach C. J. Biol. Chem. 1997; 272: 1429-1432Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (273) Google Scholar) with minor modifications. Briefly, cells transfected with FLAG-tagged MSK1 were lysed in a buffer containing 10 mm Tris (pH 7.4), 150 mm NaCl, 1 mm EDTA, 1 mm EGTA, 1% Triton X-100, 0.5% Nonidet P-40, 0.5 mm sodium vanadate, 0.2 mm phenylmethylsulfonyl fluoride, 20 μg/ml leupeptin, 20 μg/ml aprotinin, and 10% glycerol. Lysates were clarified by centrifugation. Transfected MSK1 was immunoprecipitated with the monoclonal anti-FLAG antibody bound to agarose, washed three times in lysis buffer, and resuspended in 30 μl of kinase reaction mixture containing 12.5 mm MOPS (pH 7.5), 12.5 mm β-glycerophosphate, 7.5 mm MgCl2, 0.5 mm EGTA, 0.5 mm sodium fluoride, 0.5 mm sodium vanadate, 2 μg of histone H3 (Roche Applied Science), and 20 μm ATP. After incubation at 20 °C for 30 min, kinase reaction products were analyzed by Western blotting using an antiphospho-H3-specific antibody (Cell Signaling Technology).Immunoprecipitation—For immunoprecipitation assays, cells were lysed at 4 °C in radioimmune precipitation assay buffer (20 mm Tris-HCl (pH 8), 150 mm NaCl, 5 mm MgCl2, 10% glycerol, 0.5% Nonidet P-40, 1 mm sodium vanadate, 1 mm phenylmethylsulfonyl fluoride, 20 μg/ml aprotinin, and 20 μg/ml leupeptin). Lysates were subjected to immunoprecipitation with the appropriate antibody for 2 h at 4 °C followed by absorption to Sepharose-coupled protein G for 1 h at the same temperature. Immunoprecipitates and aliquots of cell lysates before immunoprecipitation were analyzed by SDS-PAGE and immunoblotted.Confocal Microscopy—BL41 cells were transfected with GFP-Smad3 and treated 18 h later with the p38 inhibitor SB203580 and/or TGF-β as indicated. Cells were then fixed with 3% paraformaldehyde in phosphate-buffered saline for 30 min at 4 °C, stained with Hoechst, and examined by confocal fluorescence microscopy (Leica Microsystems).RESULTSp38 Pathway Is Involved in Smad-dependent Transcription—To investigate the role of p38 kinase in TGF-β-mediated transcription of target genes, we first determined, in BL41 cells, the effect of a p38 inhibitor SB203580 on different TGF-β-responsive reporters, including AP1-Lux, (CAGA)9-Lux, and p3TP-Lux. The AP1-Lux reporter contains only AP1 sites, whereas the (CAGA)9-Lux contains only concatamerized CAGA elements. The p3TP-Lux contains three AP1 sites from the collagenase-1 promoter and a CAGA box from the PAI-1 promoter. As shown in Fig. 1A, TGF-β induced a strong increase in luciferase activity from the three promoters. These effects were significantly decreased by the addition of the p38 inhibitor SB203580, which is consistent with the general notion that p38 kinase plays an important role in TGF-β-mediated transcription.Because the reporter construct contains only CAGA elements previously shown to bind complexes of Smad3 and Smad4 and to be transactivated by both TGF-β and Smad3-Smad4 (12Dennler S. Itoh S. Vivien D. ten Dijke P. Huet S. Gauthier J.M. EMBO J. 1998; 17: 3091-3100Crossref PubMed Scopus (1573) Google Scholar), these data suggest that inhibition of p38 kinase might interfere with the ability of Smads to mediate TGF-β transcriptional responses. To further dissect out the events of these signaling pathways, we also tested the effect of MKK3 and MKK6, the upstream kinases that phosphorylate and activate p38 (13Wang L. Ma R. Flavell R.A. Choi M.E. J. Biol. Chem. 2002; 277: 47257-47262Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (84) Google Scholar), on the TGF-β-dependent activation of the (CAGA)9-Lux reporter. For this purpose, we transfected BL41 cells with constitutively activated mutants of MKK3 (MKK3.E) or MKK6 (MKK6.E) together with the (CAGA)9-Lux reporter construct. Consistent with the data obtained with the p38 inhibitor, we found that overexpression of MKK3.E and MKK6.E increased the TGF-β-induced CAGA-Lux expression (Fig. 1B). This effect was even more pronounced when both kinases were coexpressed. A similar increase in the sensitivity to TGF-β-induced expression of luciferase was observed when the epithelial MDCK cells were used instead of BL41 cells (Fig. 1B). This effect was specific for MKK3 and MKK6 because as described previously (14Dennler S. Prunier C. Ferrand N. Gauthier J.M. Atfi A. J. Biol. Chem. 2000; 275: 28858-28865Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (80) Google Scholar), expression of the activated form of MKK4, by activating JNK, inhibited TGF-β-mediated transcription (not shown). To provide further evidence that p38 plays a critical role in TGF-β-mediated gene expression through Smad proteins, we tested the effect of the p38 inhibitor on the TGF-β-dependent expression of endogenous PAI-1 in MDCK cells. We chose to focus our analysis on the PAI-1 promoter as a target of Smad signaling because activation of the PAI-1 promoter by TGF-β requires the formation of a Smad3-Smad4 complex that binds the CAGA sequence (12Dennler S. Itoh S. Vivien D. ten Dijke P. Huet S. Gauthier J.M. EMBO J. 1998; 17: 3091-3100Crossref PubMed Scopus (1573) Google Scholar). Western blot analysis with anti-PAI-1 antibody demonstrated that treatment of MDCK cells with the p38 inhibitor SB203580 blocked TGF-β-mediated expression of endogenous PAI-1 (Fig. 1C). A similar analysis of PAI-1 in BL41 cells was hampered by our inability to detect PAI-1 in these cells. Therefore we analyzed in both MDCK and BL41 cells the TGF-β-dependent expression of JunB, the expression of which is upregulated by TGF-β through a similar mechanism to that of PAI-1 (15Jonk L.J. Itoh S. Heldin C.H. ten Dijke P. Kruijer W. J. Biol. Chem. 1998; 273: 21145-21152Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (510) Google Scholar). As shown in Fig. 1C, treatment of MDCK and BL41 cells with SB203580 prior to TGF-β addition strongly inhibited the accumulation of JunB in response to TGF-β signaling, suggesting that inhibition of p38 might block the ability of Smads to mediate transcriptional activation. This function of p38 likely takes place at the transcriptional level because treatment of cells with SB203580 yielded a similar decrease in the TGF-β-dependent accumulation of JunB mRNA as evidenced by reverse transcription-PCR analysis (Fig. 1D). Taken together, these results strongly support the existence of a functional relationship between Smad and p38 pathways.TGF-β-mediated Phosphorylation and Nuclear Translocation of Smad3 Are Not Modified by Inactivation of p38—The phosphorylation of Smad3 by the activated type I TGF-β receptor and its subsequent heterodimerization with Smad4 and translocation to the nucleus form the basis for a model explaining how Smad proteins work to transmit TGF-β signals from the plasma membrane to the nucleus (3Moustakas A. Souchelnytskyi S. Heldin C.H. J. Cell Sci. 2001; 114: 4359-4369Crossref PubMed Google Scholar). To understand the mechanism by which p38 controls the activation of the Smad pathway, we first investigated whether the p38 inhibitor SB203580 interfered with the ability of the activated type I receptor to phosphorylate Smad3. As shown in Fig. 2A, Smad3 phosphorylation occurred rapidly after exposure of cells to TGF-β, and these phosphorylation events were not affected by treatment of cells with SB203580. To investigate whether the inhibition of p38 could disrupt the nuclear translocation of Smad3 in response to TGF-β signaling, BL41 cells were transfected with GFP-Smad3 and treated with SB203580 prior to activation of TGF-β signaling. As shown in Fig. 2B, Smad3 was localized throughout the cytosol in unstimulated cells, whereas the addition of TGF-β induced an extensive nuclear staining. Treatment of cells with SB203580 had no effect on TGF-β-mediated nuclear translocation of Smad3 (Fig. 2B), suggesting that, in BL41 cells, inhibition of p38 does not interfere with early steps of Smad activation and translocation.Fig. 2SB203580 does not impair Smad phosphorylation and nuclear translocation. A, BL41 cells were transfected with the Myc-Smad3 expression vector and treated 18 h later with the p38 inhibitor SB203580 (SB) (20 μg/ml) 30 min before the addition of TGF-β (1 ng/ml). Protein cell extracts were obtained after treatment with TGF-β for different times, and Smad3 phosphorylation was estimated by immunoblotting using a specific antiphospho-Smad3 antibody. The same blot was rehybridized with an anti-Myc antibody. In the case of the p38 family, p38α, p38β, p38δ, and p38γ isoforms have been described as well as splicing variants of p38α and p38β (6Ono K. Han J. Cell. Signal. 2000; 12: 1-13Crossref PubMed Scopus (1382) Google Scholar). Depending on the context, the p38 family members have different roles within the cells (16Pramanik R. Qi X. Borowicz S. Choubey D. Schultz R.M. Han J. Chen G. J. Biol. Chem. 2003; 278: 4831-4839Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (125) Google Scholar). We thus sought to identify the p38 isoforms that were involved in Smad-dependent transcription. Toward this aim, BL41 cells were transfected with different vectors encoding wild type or dominant negative p38 isoforms together with the (CAGA)9-Lux reporter. We observed that only the wild type p38α isoform was able to strongly increase TGF-β-mediated luciferase activity, whereas the dominant negative mutant of this isoform greatly decreased this induction (Fig. 3A). The three other isoforms, p38β2, p38δ, and p38γ, did not have a significant effect on TGF-β-mediated luciferase expression despite efficient expression of these kinases (Fig. 3B). Notably, we were able to detect only the endogenous p38α isoform with a specific antibody in BL41 cells (Fig. 3B), which correlated with our findings that p38α was responsible for TGF-β-mediated Smad-driven transcription.Fig. 3p38 isoform α is responsible for increased Smad3 transcription. Oncogene. 2003; 22: 746-755Crossref PubMed Scopus (83) Google Scholar) leading to modification of nucleosome conformation that increases the accessibility of the transcription machinery to targeted promoters. To determine the mechanism by which p38 acts to enhance TGF-β/Smad signaling, we first investigated the ability of TGF-β signaling to induce the phosphorylation of MSK1. For this, COS7 cells were transfected with wild type MSK1 in the absence or in the presence of the constitutively activated type I receptor, and the extent of MSK1 phosphorylation was examined with an antiphospho-MSK1 antibody that specifically recognizes p38-phosphorylated MSK1. In cells transfected with MSK1, no phosphorylation of MSK1 could be detected in the absence of TGF-β signaling (Fig. 4A). However, coexpression of MSK1 with the constitutively activated type I receptor resulted in a strong phosphorylation of MSK1. This effect was dependent on the activation of TGF-β signaling because overexpression of the wild type form of the type I receptor failed to increase MSK1 phosphorylation (Fig. 4D). To test whether TGF-β induces the phosphorylation of endogenous MSK1, BL41 cells were treated with TGF-β for various time periods, and the extent of phosphorylation of MSK1 was analyzed with antiphospho-MSK1. Fig. 4B shows that the exposure of cells to TGF-β caused a significant and persistent phosphorylation of MSK1. We also investigated the ability of TGF-β to induce the activation of MSK1 by using an immunocomplex kinase assay with histone H3 as substrate. As shown in Fig. 5A, expression of wild type MSK1 in BL41 cells increased the sensitivity of BL41 cells to TGF-β, suggesting that MSK1 might function as a component of the TGF-β signaling pathway. Consistent with this hypothesis, we observed that expression of a dominant negative mutant of MSK1 inhibited TGF-β-mediated activation of the (CAGA)9-Lux reporter (Fig. 5A). Microdiamonds from the Akluilâk minette dykes (Nunavut, Canada) are similar to diamonds formed in subducted metamorphic rocks. High concentrations of unaggregated nitrogen and positive delta(15)N suggest that the microdiamonds formed within rocks subducted to ultrahigh pressures before being sampled by the minette magma 1.8 billion years ago. This ultrahigh pressure metamorphism in North America, probably related to the Trans-Hudson orogen (about 2 billion years ago), extends the occurrence of ultrahigh pressure metamorphism from 0.6 billion years to before 1.8 billion years ago and suggests that Phanerozoic-type subductions were active by the Early Proterozoic.

We have investigated the role of the mitochondrial pathway during cell death following serum and nerve growth factor (NGF)/dibutyryl cyclic AMP (Bt2cAMP) withdrawal in undifferentiated or NGF/Bt2cAMP-differentiated PC12 cells, respectively. Holocytochrome c, Smac/DIABLO, and Omi/HtrA2 are released rapidly following trophic factor deprivation in PC12 cells. Bcl-2 and Akt inhibited this release. The protection, however, persisted longer in differentiated PC12 cells. In differentiated, but not undifferentiated cells, Bcl-2 and Akt also inhibited apoptosis downstream of holocytochrome c release. Thus, undifferentiated PC12 cells showed marked sensitivity to induction of apoptosis by microinjected cytochrome c even in the presence of NGF, Bcl-2, or Akt. In contrast, in differentiated cells these factors suppressed cell death. Consistent with these observations, in vitro processing of procaspase 9 in response to cytochrome c was observed in extracts from undifferentiated but not differentiated cells expressing Akt or Bcl-2. Endogenous caspase 9 was cleaved during cell death, whereas dominant negative caspase 9 inhibited cell death. The results from determining the role of inhibitors of apoptosis (IAPs) suggest that acquisition of inhibition by IAPs is part of the differentiation program. Ubiquitin-ΔN-AVPI Smac/DIABLO induced cell death in differentiated cells only. c-IAP-2 is unregulated in differentiated cells, whereas X-linked IAP levels decreased in these cells coincident with cell death. Moreover, expressing X-linked IAP rendered undifferentiated cells resistant to microinjected cytochrome c. Overall, the inhibitory regulation, of cell death at the level of release of mitochondrial apoptogenic factors and at post-mitochondrial activation of caspase 9 observed in differentiated PC12 cells, is reduced or absent in the undifferentiated counterparts. The protection, however, persisted longer in differentiated PC12 cells. In differentiated, but not undifferentiated cells, Bcl-2 and Akt also inhibited apoptosis downstream of holocytochrome c release.
